subject: RE: [junit] Testing state cover
msgSnippet: Hi Jin, I am not David, but I want to make a comment. David provided a general recipe for testing algorithms. Since you are designer of the algorithm, at the
messageBody:
Hi Jin,

I am not David, but I want to make a comment.
David provided a general recipe for testing
algorithms.
Since you are designer of the algorithm, at the very
minimum you have a collection of state machines in
mind that you probably ran through manually to verify
correctness of your solution.

One way of testing would be to test that you find
shortest path for SMs that you manually solved.
This definetely does not provide assurance
that your test will work for all SMs.
As you find other cases of SMs add them to your suite
of tests.

So every test so far will look like
1. Hardcode SM
2. Run Algorithm
3. Assert shortest path is s0->s1->...->s?
etc.

In addition you could test given an existing already
tried and true algorithm. Lets say that your
algorithm (Jun's Algorithm) is super smart and does
not have to cover all
possible state transitions to find shortest path.
Lets say algorithm A1 exists that is greedy and is
guaranteed to find solution and you know that
the software library implementing it is "working"
you can do something like this.

1. Hardcode SM (even if you don't know solution)
2. solution1 = Run Algorithm A1
3. solutionJune = Run Algorithm June
4. Assert solution1 same as solutionJune

Anyway, I hope this provides you with some additional
help.

Thanks, Mikhail




--- jin beck <jinq24@...> wrote:

> Hi. David.
>
> Yeah, Could you give me some more details where I
> can get the examples and
> how to test them?
> Or any web materials.
>
> Thanks a lot.
>
> Regards,
>
>
> >From: "David Jackman"
> <david.jackman@...>
> >Reply-To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> >To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
> >Subject: RE: [junit] Testing state cover
> >Date: Thu, 1 Sep 2005 10:31:12 -0600
> >
> >The formula works like this (it doesn't really
> matter what your code
> >actually does). Your library/algorithm takes some
> input and produces
> >some output. Your tests should call your library
> with different input
> >and then verify (assert) that the output is correct
> in each case. You
> >can do this on the whole library as well as
> individual methods on
> >individual classes.
> >
> >Hope this helps; call back if you need more detail
> (or Google for the
> >basic examples--they're all over).
> >..David..
> >
> >________________________________
> >
> >From: junit@yahoogroups.com
> [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
> >haggaikeithme
> >Sent: Thursday, September 01, 2005 9:02 AM
> >To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> >Subject: [junit] Testing state cover
> >
> >
> >Hi. I have implemented an algorithm in Java which
> produces state
> >cover, shortest paths to get another statefrom
> start state, from a
> >finite state machine(FSM). How can I test whether
> this has produced
> >right paths using JUnit test.
> >
> >Thanks,
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
